column1: Fall River is a city in Bristol County
column2: Massachusetts
column3: United States. The City of Fall River's population was 88
column4: 857 at the 2010 census
column5: making it the tenth-largest city in the state. Located along the eastern shore of Mount Hope Bay at the mouth of the Taunton River
column6: the city became famous during the 19th century as the leading textile manufacturing center in the United States. While the textile industry has long since moved on
column7: its impact on the city's culture and landscape remains to this day. Fall River's official motto is "We'll Try"
column8: dating back to the aftermath of the Great Fire of 1843. It is also nicknamed the "Scholarship City" because Irving Fradkin founded Dollars for Scholars there in 1958. In 2017
column9: mayor Jasiel Correia introduced the "Make It Here" slogan as part of a citywide rebranding effort.Fall River is known for the Lizzie Borden case
column11: its numerous 19th-century textile mills and Battleship Cove
column12: the world's largest collection of World War II naval vessels and the home of the battleship USS Massachusetts. Fall River is also the only city in the United States to have its city hall located over an interstate highway

column1: At the time of the establishment of the Plymouth Colony in 1620
column2: the area that would one day become Troy City was inhabited by the Pokanoket Wampanoag tribe
column3: headquartered at Mount Hope in what is now Bristol
column4: Rhode Island. The "falling" river that the name Fall River refers to is the Quequechan River (pronounced "quick-a-shan" by locals) which flows through the city
column5: dropping steeply into the bay. Quequechan is a Wampanoag word believed to mean "falling river" or "leaping/falling waters." During the 1960s
column6: Interstate 195 was constructed through the city along the length of the Quequechan River. The portion west of Plymouth Avenue was routed underground through a series of box culverts
column7: while much of the eastern section "mill pond" was filled in for the highway embankment.

column2: Freetown was settled at Assonet Bay by members of the Plymouth Colony
column3: as part of Freeman's Purchase
column4: which included the northern part of what is now Fall River. In 1683
column5: Freetown was incorporated as a town within the colony. The southern part of what is now Fall River was incorporated as the town of Tiverton as part of the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1694
column6: a few years after the merger with Plymouth Colony. In 1746
column7: in the settlement of a colonial boundary dispute between Rhode Island and Massachusetts
column8: Tiverton was annexed to Rhode Island
column9: along with Little Compton and what is now Newport County
column10: Rhode Island. The boundary was then placed approximately at what is now Columbia Street.

column2: Benjamin Church
column3: a hero of King Philip's War established a saw mill
column4: grist mill
column5: and a fulling mill on the Quequechan River. In 1714
column6: Church sold his land
column7: along with the water rights to Richard Borden of Tiverton and his brother Joseph. This transaction would prove to be extremely valuable 100 years later
column8: helping to establish the Borden family as the leaders in the development of Fall River's textile industry.

column1: During the 18th century the area consisted mostly of small farms and relatively few inhabitants. In 1778
column2: the Battle of Freetown
column3: was fought here during the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783) after British raids badly damaged Bristol and Warren. The militia of Fall River
column4: at that time known as Freetown
column5: put up a stronger defense against a British force.

column2: Fall River was separated from Freetown and officially incorporated as its own town. A year later
column3: Fall River changed its name to "Troy." The name "Troy" was used for 30 years and was officially changed back to Fall River on February 12
column4: 1834. During this period
column5: Fall River was governed by a three-member Board of Selectmen
column6: until it became a City in 1854.

column2: The Fall River Female Anti Slavery Society was formed (one of the many anti slavery societies in New England) to promote abolition and to allow a women's space to conduct social activism. There was an initial group
column3: which was wary of allowing free black full membership
column4: so a second group (this one) was formed in response by Elizabeth Buffum Chace and her sisters
column5: who were committed to allowing free black women membership.

column1: A delegate from the group was sent to the Anti-Slavery Convention of American Women
column2: a Philadelphia convention in 1838. Her name was Sarah G. Buffman
column3: and she signed all three of the statements that the convention's delegates agreed on.In July 1843
column4: the first great fire in Fall River's history destroyed much of the town center
column5: including the Atheneum
column6: which housed the Skeleton in Armor which had been discovered in a sand bank in 1832 near what is now the corner of Hartwell and Fifth Street.

column2: the southern part of what is now Fall River (south of Columbia Street) would remain part of Tiverton
column3: Rhode Island. In 1856
column4: the town of Tiverton
column5: Rhode Island voted to split off its industrial northern section as Fall River
column6: Rhode Island. In 1861
column7: after decades of dispute
column8: the United States Supreme Court moved the state boundary to what is now State Avenue
column9: unifying both Fall Rivers as a city in Massachusetts (among other changes; see History of Massachusetts § Rhode Island eastern border). For many years RI and Massachusetts fought over parts of cities and states boundaries. Also the state since Roger Williams started Providence plantations when he started it as a land. Eventually changed to Rhode Island and Providence Plantations to england to be a colony. At the time Plantations means  land/farm. During this they eventually did change Massachusetts traded the other half of the city of Pawtucket to RI. The division of Pawtucket was the River. The birthplace of the American Revolution. Massachusetts also trade Rumford area which is part of East Providence. FallRiver and Seekonk became part of Rhode Island’s trade time gain their land.

column1: The early establishment of the textile industry in Fall River grew out of the developments made in nearby Rhode Island beginning with Samuel Slater at Pawtucket in 1793. In 1811
column2: Col. Joseph Durfee
column3: the Revolutionary War veteran and hero of the Battle of Freetown in 1778 built the Globe Manufactory (a spinning mill) at the outlet of Cook Pond on Dwelly St. near what is now Globe Four Corners in the city's South End. (It was part of Tiverton
column4: Rhode Island at the time.) While Durfee's mill was never very successful
column5: it marked the beginning of the city's rise in the textile business.

column1: The real development of Fall River's industry
column2: however
column3: would occur along the falling river from which it was named
column4: about a mile north of Durfee's first mill. The Quequechan River
column5: with its eight falls
column6: combined to make Fall River the best tidewater privilege in southern New England. It was perfect for industrialization—big enough for profit and expansion
column7: yet small enough to be developed by local capital without interference from Boston.The Fall River Manufactory was established by David Anthony and others in 1813. That same year
column8: the Troy Cotton & Woolen Manufactory was also founded
column9: by a group of investors led by Oliver Chace
column11: who had worked as a carpenter for Samuel Slater in his early years. The Troy Mill opened in 1814
column12: at the upper end of the falls.

column2: Colonel Richard Borden established the Fall River Iron Works
column3: along with Maj. Bradford Durfee at the lower part of the Quequechan River. Durfee was a shipwright
column4: and Borden was the owner of a grist mill. After an uncertain start
column5: in which some early investors pulled out
column6: the Fall River Iron Works was incorporated in 1825. The Iron Works began producing nails
column7: bar stock
column8: and other items such as bands for casks in the nearby New Bedford whaling industry. They soon gained a reputation for producing nails of high quality
column9: and business flourished. In 1827
column10: Col. Borden began regular steamship service to Providence
column11: Rhode Island.The American Print Works was established in 1835 by Holder Borden
column12: uncle of Colonel Richard. With the leadership of the Borden family
column13: the American Print Works (later known as the American Printing Company) became the largest and most important textile company in the city
column14: employing thousands at its peak in the early 20th century. Richard Borden also constructed the Metacomet Mill in 1847
column15: which today is the oldest remaining textile (cloth-producing) mill in the city

column2: the Quequechan's power had been all but maximized. The Massasoit Steam Mill was established in 1846
column3: above the dam near the end of Pleasant Street. However
column4: it would be another decade or so when improvements in the steam engine by George Corliss would enable the construction of the first large steam-powered mill in the city
column5: the Union Mills in 1859.

column1: The advantage of being able to import bales of cotton and coal to fuel the steam engines to Fall River's deep water harbor
column2: and ship out the finished goods also by water
column3: made Fall River the choice of a series of cotton mill magnates. The first railroad line serving Fall River
column4: The Fall River Branch Railroad
column5: was incorporated in 1844 and opened in 1845. Two years later
column7: the first regular steamboat service to New York City began. The Fall River Line as it came to be known operated until 1937
column8: and for many years
column9: was the preferred way to travel between Boston and Manhattan. The Old Colony Railroad and Fall River Railroad merged in 1854
column10: forming the Old Colony and Fall River Railroad.

column2: Fall River was officially incorporated as a city
column3: and had a population of about 12
column4: 000. Its first mayor was James Buffington.

column1: Fall River profited well from the American Civil War and was in a fine position to take advantage of the prosperity that followed. By 1868
column2: it had surpassed Lowell as the leading textile city in America with over 500
column3: 000 spindles.

column2: a "most dramatic expansion" of the city occurred: 15 new corporations were founded
column3: building 22 new mills throughout the city
column4: while some of the older mills expanded. The city's population increased by 20
column5: 000 people during these two years
column6: while overall mill capacity doubled to more than 1
column8: 000 spindles.By 1876
column9: the city had one sixth of all New England cotton capacity and one half of all print cloth production. The "Spindle City" as it became known
column10: was second in the world to only Manchester

column1: To house the thousands of new workers
column2: mostly Irish and French Canadian immigrants during these years
column3: over 12
column4: 000 units of company housing were built. Unlike the well-spaced boardinghouses of the tidy cottages of Rhode Island
column5: worker housing in Fall River consisted of thousands of wood-framed multi-family tenements
column6: usually three-floor "triple-deckers" with up to six apartments. Many more privately owned tenements supplemented the company housing.During the 19th century
column7: Fall River became famous for the granite rock on which much of the city is built. Several granite quarries operated during this time
column8: the largest of which was the Beattie Granite Quarry
column9: near what is now North Quarry Street
column10: near the corner of Locust. Many of the mills in the city were built from this native stone
column11: and it was highly regarded as a building material for many public buildings and private homes alike. The Chateau-sur-Mer mansion in Newport
column12: Rhode Island is perhaps the best example of Fall River granite being used for private home construction.

column1: While most of the mills "above the hill" were constructed from native Fall River granite
column2: nearly all of their counterparts along the Taunton River and Mount Hope Bay were made of red brick. This was due to the high costs and impracticality associated with transporting the rock through the city and down the hill
column3: where there were no rail lines because of the steep grades. (One notable exception is the Sagamore Mills on North Main Street
column4: which were constructed from similar rock quarried in Freetown and brought to the site by rail.)

column1: Fall River rode the wave of economic prosperity well into the early 20th century. During this time
column2: the city boasted several fancy hotels
column3: theaters
column4: and a bustling downtown. As the city continually expanded during the late 19th century
column5: its leaders built several fine parks
column6: schools
column7: streetcar lines
column8: a public water supply
column9: and sewerage system to meet the needs of its growing population.

column2: Fall River was the headquarters of the E. P. Charlton & Company chain of five and ten cent stores.  Founded at Fall River in 1890 by Seymour H. Knox and Earle Perry Charlton as the Knox & Charlton Five and Ten Cent Store
column3: by the time of its merger with several other retailers to form the F. W. Woolworth Company in 1912
column4: Charlton operated fifty-eight stores in the United States and Canada.

column1: In 1920 the population of Fall River peaked at 120
The cotton mills of Fall River had built their business largely on one product: print cloth. About 1910
column2: the city's largest employer
column3: the American Printing Company (APC)
column4: employed 6
column5: 000 people and was the largest company printer of cloth in the world. Dozens of other city mills solely produced cloth to be printed at the APC. The city's industry had all its eggs in one
column6: very large basket.

column1: World War I had provided a general increase in demand for textiles
column2: and many of the mills of New England benefited during this time. The post-war economy quickly slowed
column3: however
column4: and production quickly outpaced demand. The Northern mills faced serious competition from their Southern counterparts due to factors such as lower labor and transportation costs
column5: as well as the South's large investment in new machinery and other equipment. In 1923
column6: Fall River faced the first wave of mill closures. Some mills merged and were able to limp along until the late 1920s. By the 1930s and the Great Depression
column7: many more mills were out of business and the city was bankrupt. A few somehow managed to survive through World War II and into the 1950s.

column1: The worst fire in Fall River's history occurred on the evening of February 2
column2: 1928. It began when workers were dismantling the recently vacated Pocasset Mill. During the night the fire spread quickly and wiped out a large portion of downtown. City Hall was spared but was badly damaged. Today
column3: many of the structures near the corner of North Main and Bedford Street date from the early 1930s
column4: as they were rebuilt soon after the fire.

column1: The once mighty American Printing Company finally closed for good in 1934. In 1937
column2: their huge plant waterfront on Water Street was acquired by the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company and soon employed 2
column3: 600 people. In October 1941
column4: just a few weeks before the attack on Pearl Harbor
column5: a huge fire broke out in the old 1860s' main building of the print works. The fire was a major setback to the U.S. war effort
column6: as $15 million in raw rubber (30
column7: 000 lbs.) was lost in the inferno.With the demise of the textile industry
column8: many of the city's mills were occupied by smaller companies
column9: some in the garment industry
column10: traditionally based in the New York City area but attracted to New England by the lure of cheap factory space and an eager workforce in need of jobs. The garment industry survived in the city well into the 1990s but has also largely become a victim of globalization and foreign competition.

column1: In the 1960s the city's landscape was drastically transformed with the construction of the Braga Bridge and Interstate 195
column2: which cut directly through the heart of the city. In the wake of the highway building boom
column3: the city lost some great pieces of its history. The Quequechan River was filled in and re-routed for much of its length. The historic falls
column4: which had given the city its name
column5: were diverted into underground culverts. A series of elevated steel viaducts was constructed as to access the new Braga Bridge. Many historic buildings were demolished
column6: including the Old City Hall
column7: the 150-year-old Troy Mills
column8: the Second Granite Block (built after the 1928 fire)
column9: as well as other 19th century brick-and-mortar buildings near Old City Hall.

column2: where its predecessor was
column3: the new city hall was opened in 1976
column4: after years of construction delays and quality control problems. Built in the Brutalist style popular in the 1960s and 1970s
column5: the new city hall drew complaints from city workers and residents almost immediately.

column1: In 1970 the Valle's Steak House chain opened one if its landmark restaurants on William S. Canning Boulevard. The steak house was popular with Fall River residents but economic challenges caused the chain to close all of its restaurants in the 1980s.Also during the 1970s
column2: several modern apartment high-rise towers were built throughout the city
column3: many part of the Fall River Housing Authority. There were two built near Milliken Boulevard
column4: two on Pleasant Street in Flint Village
column5: another on South Main Street
column6: and in the north end off Robeson Street. Today
column7: these high-rises mostly house the elderly.

column2: the city opened the new B.M.C. Durfee High School in the north end
column3: replacing the historic Rock Street masterpiece that had become overcrowded and outdated for use as a high school. The "new" Durfee is one of the largest high schools in Massachusetts.

column2: there has been a considerable amount of new development in the North end of the city
column3: with many new single- and multi-family housing developments
column4: particularly along North Main Street.

column2: Fall River was ranked the 77th most dangerous city in the United States.Fall River is also the most dangerous city in Massachusetts and second most dangerous city in New England.

column3: a cannabis dispensary opened in Fall River
column4: becoming only the sixth dispensary in Massachusetts and the first in Southeastern Massachusetts to open to anyone 21 years or older.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 40.2 square miles (104.2 km2)
column3: of which 33.1 square miles (85.8 km2) is land and 7.1 square miles (18.4 km2)
column5: is water.Water power from the Quequechan River and natural granite helped form and shape Fall River into the city it is today. Fall River granite is quarried here. The Quequechan River once flowed through downtown unrestricted
column6: providing water power for the mills and
column7: in the last 1⁄2 mile (0.8 km) of its length
column8: down a series of eight steep waterfalls falling 128 feet (39 m) into the Taunton River at the head of the deep Mount Hope Bay.

column1: Fall River was the only city on the East Coast of the United States to have had an exposed waterfall in part of its downtown area; it flowed less than 1⁄2 mile (0.8 km) into a sheltered harbor at the edge of downtown. Fall River has two large lakes (originally one lake) and a large portion of protected woodlands on the eastern part of the city
column2: which is higher in elevation
column3: with the Quequechan River draining out of the ponds and flowing 2.5 miles (4.0 km) through the heart of the city
column4: emptying out an estimated 26 million US gallons (98×10^6 l) per day into the deep Mount Hope Bay/Taunton River estuary in the western part of the city.

column1: The city lies on the eastern border of Mount Hope Bay
column2: which begins at the mouth of the Taunton River starting south from the Charles M. Braga Jr. Memorial Bridge. The greater portion of the city is built on hillsides rising quite abruptly from the water's edge to a height of more than 200 feet (60 m). From the summits of these hills the country extends back in a comparatively level table-land
column3: on which a large section of the city now stands.

column1: Two miles (3 km) eastward from the shore lies a chain of deep and narrow ponds
column2: eight miles (13 km) long
column3: with an average width of three-quarters of a mile
column4: and covering an area of 3
column5: 500 acres (14 km2). These ponds are supplied by springs and brooks
column6: draining a watershed of 20
column7: 000 acres (81 km2). The northern pond is the North Watuppa Pond
column8: the city's main reservoir. The southern pond is the South Watuppa Pond. Where the two ponds meet is called "The Narrows." East of the North Watuppa Pond is the Watuppa Reservation that includes several thousand acres of forest-land for water supply protection that extends north into the Freetown-Fall River State Forest
column9: and east to the Copicut Reservoir. Copicut Pond is located on the border of Dartmouth in North Dartmouth's Hixville section that borders Fall River. Copicut Hill
column10: the highest point in Fall River
column11: is located between North Watuppa Pond and the Copicut Reservoir and has a summit elevation of greater than 404 feet (123 m) above sea level.

column1: The Quequechan River breaks out of its bed in the west part of the South Watuppa Pond
column2: just west of The Narrows
column3: and flows through the city (partially underground in conduits) where it falls to a channel leading to what is now Heritage State Park at Battleship Cove on the Taunton River. The Quequechan River originally flowed unconfined over an almost level course for more than a mile. In the last half-mile (800 m) of its progress it rushes down the hillside in a narrow
column4: precipitous
column5: rocky channel
column6: creating the falls for which Fall River is named. In this distance the total fall is about 132 feet (40 m). and the volume of water 122 cubic feet (3.5 m3) per second.

column1: Originally an attractive feature of the landscape
column2: the Quequechan has seldom been visible since it was covered over by cotton mills and the Bay Colony Railroad line in the 19th century. As the Quequechan became an underground feature of the industrial landscape
column3: it also became a sewer. In the 20th century the mills were abandoned and some of them burned
column4: exposing the falls once more. Because of highway construction in the 1960s
column5: the waterfalls were buried under Interstate 195
column6: which crosses the Taunton River at Battleship Cove. Plans exist to "daylight" the falls
column7: restore or re-create them
column8: and build a green belt with a bicycle path along the Quequechan River.

Fall River retains a vibrant mix of cultures from around the globe. While the distinct ethnic neighborhoods formed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries have changed over the years
column2: the legacy of immigrants who came to work in the mills can be found in the various parishes and restaurants throughout the city. This heritage is commemorated by the 19 flags which make up the "Banners of Allegiance" at Gromada Plaza
column3: across from City Hall. Erected in 1979 (and restored in 2019)
column4: this landmark commemorates the diverse nationalities of Fall River's residents.The city is host to many ethnic festivals throughout the year. The largest
column5: the Great Holy Ghost Festival
column6: occurs each August at Kennedy Park and attracts over 200
column7: 000 visitors
column8: everywhere from Canada
column9: to Portugal. The feast is held over a total of four days.Each summer
column10: the city uses its waterfront at Heritage State Park and Battleship Cove for a Fourth of July fireworks display. For many years the waterfront also hosted the annual Fall River Celebrates America Festival
column11: sponsored by the Fall River Chamber of Commerce. The event was suspended in 2010
column12: due to lack of financial support. However
column13: the Chamber hopes to have the event again in 2011
column14: to mark its 100th anniversary.In recent years
column15: different groups have made an effort to increase awareness in the arts in the city
column16: using vacant mill space for studios and performance centers
column17: such as the Narrows Center for the Arts on Anawan Street. A proposal is in place to revitalize the downtown area by the creation of an Arts District. Along with the art centers being established throughout the city
column18: Fall River has numerous Portuguese/Community Bands throughout the city that perform throughout the year.

column1: Fall River remains a predominantly Roman Catholic city and is the seat of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Fall River
column2: located at St. Mary's Cathedral on Second Street
column3: formed in the 1850s by Irish immigrants. Also on Columbia Street is located Santo Christo Parish known as the Mother Church of the Portuguese Parishes in the Fall River Diocese. The Church was Established in 1892 to serve the local Portuguese community that Immigrated predominately from the São Miguel Island of Azores. Other imposing Catholic churches include St. Anne's Church at the top of Kennedy Park
column4: Good Shepherd Church (formerly Saint Patrick's) in the South End
column5: and the former Notre Dame de Lourdes in the Flint neighborhood
column6: which was destroyed in a spectacular blaze on May 10
column7: 1982. At the time of the city's peak population in 1920
column8: there were over two dozen Catholic parishes existing throughout the city
column9: with each ethnic enclave having its own parish. In recent years
column10: the diocese has merged several parishes in the city
column13: bringing the total number of parishes in the diocese to fifteen as of 2013. St. Louis the King Church closed in 2000.Historically
column14: the Highlands neighborhood was predominantly Protestant
column15: with several churches in the area of North Main and Rock Streets
column16: notably including the Central Congregational Church and the First Congregational Church
column17: known for hosting many New England luminaries before its demise in a fire in the 1980s.

column1: German Jewish settlers were attracted to Fall River starting in the 1860s and 1870s. The 1880s and 1890s saw the arrival of Russian Jewish immigrants. At the start of the 20th Century
column2: Fall River was home to three synagogues. The Jewish community were engaged in peddling
column3: retail
column4: and clothing stores. Temple Beth-El was founded in 1924 on High Street. In 1970 there were three congregations serving 4
column5: 000 Jews in Fall River; by 2008 that number had declined to less than 1
column6: 000.Various other ethno-religious groups also live in the city. Recent arrivals from Cambodia
column7: and India also maintain temples in the city such as Wat Udomsaharatanaram and BAPS Shri Swaminarayanwasi. With the addition of religious centers for Theravada Buddhism and Hinduism
column8: the diversity of faith supports the spiritualism for the citizens of Fall River.

column1: The city is led by the mayor-council form of government. There are nine at-large city councillors. The Mayor along with the City Administrator lead and manage the city's day-to-day operations.
The city's police department is consolidated into a large central police station. There are six fire stations located around the city. The Fire Headquarters is located on Commerce Drive
column2: just across from the former Fall River Municipal Airport. There are four post offices in the city
column3: located in Flint Village
column4: the South End Branch (near Globe Corners)
column5: Highland Station and the central branch just behind Government Center
column6: a post office modeled after the James Farley Post Office
column7: the New York City main post office behind Penn Plaza. The central branch was named after the late Sgt. Robert Barrett in May 2011
column8: a soldier born in the city
column9: who died in Afghanistan in 2010. The post office will now be known as the "Robert Barrett Post Office." The city is also home to a Superior Court
column10: a District Court and the new Bristol County Court House
column11: located in the former B.M.C. Durfee High School building on Rock Street. A new District Court is at 186 South Main Street.

column1: Fall River is represented by three separate Massachusetts House of Representatives districts (one of which represents the majority of the city) and is represented by Carole Fiola (6th Bristol)
column2: Alan Silvia (7th Bristol)

column4: which includes the city and the towns of Freetown
column5: Lakeville
column6: Rochester
column7: Somerset and Swansea.Fall River is patrolled by the Third Barracks of Troop D of the Massachusetts State Police
column8: based out of Dartmouth.

column2: the city is divided between two congressional districts. The city is represented by Joseph Kennedy III and Bill Keating.

column3: and was the first Portuguese grammar school to open in the United States. As of 2011 the majority of the students are ethnic Portuguese

column1: The University of Massachusetts Dartmouth has two branches in the city: the Professional and Continuing Education Center located at 139 South Main Street (in the 1917 Cherry & Webb building)
column2: and the Advanced Technical & Manufacturing Center at the Narrows
column3: on the former site of the Kerr Mills. The school traces half of its roots back to the city; the Bradford Durfee Textile School was founded there in 1899
column4: with its original 1904 building on the corner of Durfee and Bank Streets still standing. The building was also the original home of Bristol Community College

The Eastern Nazarene College offers Adult Studies/LEAD classes in Fall River as well. It also has GED programs and a recording studio.

column1: Fall River established its public library in 1860. In fiscal year 2008
column2: the city of Fall River spent 0.56% ($1
column4: 945) of its budget on its public library—some $11 per person.The main location of the Fall River Public Library is located at 104 North Main Street
column5: within the Downtown Fall River Historic District. It opened in 1899
column6: and was designed by architect Ralph Adams Cram in the Renaissance Revival style. It is constructed from native Fall River granite. The building underwent an extensive renovation during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

column1: The public library system also includes two branches; the South End Branch located at 58 Arch Street
column2: and the East End Branch located at 1386 Pleasant Street.

column1: Fall River has always been considered a transportation hub for the South Coast and Mount Hope Bay areas
column2: due to its location along the Taunton River. In addition to the Fall River Line (discussed in the "History" section)
column3: Slade's Ferry ran from Fall River to Somerset since the 17th century
column4: connecting the two communities. In 1875
column5: Slade's Ferry Bridge was opened
column6: connecting the two cities for trolley lines as well as cart (and later
column7: car) traffic. It was a two-tiered steel swing-span bridge
column8: extending over 1
column9: 100 feet (340 m) from Remington Avenue to the intersection of Wilbur Avenue
column10: Riverside Avenue and Brayton Avenue in Somerset. This bridge was in use until 1970
column11: when it was closed and subsequently demolished. (The path of the bridge is now roughly marked by twin sets of power lines crossing the river.) In 1903
column12: the state authorized a second bridge
column15: 922-foot (281 m) long drawbridge ending at its namesake street
column18: is still partially standing today. The third bridge to span the river in Fall River was the Charles M. Braga Jr. Memorial Bridge. Started in 1959 and opened in the spring of 1966
column19: the six-lane cantilever truss highway bridge spans 1.2 miles (1.9 km) and was part of the project to build Interstate 195.

column2: problems began to arise with the Brightman Street Bridge. It was often closed for repairs
column3: which put much strain on local traffic
column4: forced to take long detours across the nearby Braga Bridge. In 1983 plans were being made to build a new bridge 1
column5: 500 feet (460 m) north of the current one
column6: which would directly link with Route 138. Plans were put on hold in 1989 due to Coast Guard concerns
column7: but construction of the new span began in the late 1990s and continued until late 2011. Named the Veterans Memorial Bridge
column8: in honor of all local veterans
column9: it was formally dedicated on September 11

column1: Interstate 195 is now the main point of entry for the city
column2: entering via the Charles M. Braga Jr. Memorial Bridge from Somerset and leaving over "The Narrows
column3: a small strip of land between the North and South Watuppa Ponds that carries Interstate 195, Route 6 and Old Bedford Road into Fall River from Westport as the roads make their way east towards New Bedford and Cape Cod. The highway covers much of the old path parallel to the Bay Colony/New Bedford Cape Cod Railroad as well the original path of the Quequechan River, and has resulted in a unique situation—it is one of the few highways in the country with a city hall (officially known as Fall River Government Center") standing directly on top of it. The tunnel which passes below Government Center was the site of an accident in March 1999
column4: in which a cement ceiling tile
column5: its supports worn away by corrosion
column6: collapsed
column7: landed on several cars but causing only minor injuries. The incident caused major traffic problems in the area
column8: and bears a striking resemblance to the incident involving the I-90 tunnel collapse (a part of the Big Dig) in 2006.

column2: Fall River is also served by four other major routes
column3: which include Route 6 (which passes over the Brightman Street Bridge going west before joining the city grid then continuing east into Westport); Route 24
column4: a 2 Lane North/South divided highway linking Fall River to Boston and Newport; Route 79
column5: another divided highway that begins at the Braga Bridge and continues northbound to Route 24; Route 138
column6: which also enters the city via the Brightman Street Bridge before joining the city grid
column7: passing southwards towards Aquidneck Island; and Route 81
column8: which begins near the former site of the Quequechan River and travels south into Tiverton. Additionally
column9: Route 177 clips the extreme southern part of the city for less than 0.25-mile (0.40 km) between Westport and Tiverton. Route 138
column12: and US 6 are based upon old Indian routes and trails.

column1: The Fall River State Pier is still in operation
column2: bringing goods into the city via boat and by a freight train line which travels north from the pier parallel to Route 79. Freight service is currently provided by the Massachusetts Coastal Railroad. Plans are in the works to add 2 commuter rail service lines known as the South Coast Rail "projects" to extend from Stoughton along the current Stoughton Line of the MBTA Commuter Rail Line
column3: which would connect Fall River as well as Taunton and New Bedford to the MBTA rail system to points to and from Boston and other points around the state. Presently
column4: the nearest commuter rail stations are in Attleboro
column5: 29 miles west.

column1: Fall River serves as the terminus for a passenger ferry line connecting to Newport

column1: Fall River has a rich soccer history. The game was first introduced to the city in the 1880s by the arrival of immigrants from Lancashire and Glasgow who worked in the local textile industry. In later decades the arrival of immigrants from Portugal helped to sustain the game's popularity. Between 1888 and 1892 teams from Fall River won the American Cup five times in succession. One of these teams
column2: Fall River Rovers also won the 1917 National Challenge Cup. The star and captain of the team was local-born Thomas Swords who
column4: captained the United States in their first official international.

column2: Fall River Marksmen were one of the most successful soccer clubs in the United States and were American soccer champions on seven occasions. In 1932
column3: another club
column4: Fall River F.C.
column5: were also champions.

column1: The Marksmen also won the National Challenge Cup four times. Among their most notable players were Billy Gonsalves and Bert Patenaude
column2: who were both raised in Fall River. In 1930 they both played for the United States at the first ever soccer World Cup. Patenaude is also credited with scoring the first ever hat-trick in World Cup history. He scored all three goals in the United States' 3–0 victory over Paraguay.

Ponta Delgada S.C. became one of the most successful amateur teams in the United States. In 1947 the team was selected en masse to represent the United States at the North American soccer championship. In 1950 two of their local born players
column3: Ed Souza and John Souza
column4: played at the World Cup and helped the United States defeat England
column5: 1–0.On January 18
column6: 2011 Andrew Sousa was drafted by New England Revolution
column7: thus becoming the first ever Fall River native to play in Major League Soccer.
